# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.offline as py
import warnings

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 5GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All"

source.14ccf28c:
from colorama import Fore, Style

nRowsRead = 1000 # specify 'None' if want to read whole file
# ham_lyrics.csv has 3634 rows in reality, but we are only loading/previewing the first 1000 rows
df = pd.read_csv('../input/human-development-index-list/human_development_index.csv', delimiter=',', nrows = nRowsRead)
df.dataframeName = 'human-development-index-list/human_development_index.csv'
nRow, nCol = df.shape
print(f'There are {nRow} rows and {nCol} columns')
df.head()
print(Fore.MAGENTA + 'Data shape: ',Style.RESET_ALL,df.shape)
df
source.78aad63d:
#Code by Daniboy370  https://www.kaggle.com/daniboy370/tutorial-web-scraping

import plotly.express as px

thres = 1.3
df_th = df.drop(df[ df['HDI'] > thres ].index)

# color pallete @ https://plotly.com/python/builtin-colorscales/
fig = px.choropleth(df_th, locations='Country or Territory',
                color="Rank", hover_name="Country or Territory",
                    color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Sunset, projection="orthographic")
fig.update_layout(title={'text':'Countries Ranking', 'y':0.95, 'x':0.5, 'xanchor':'center', 'yanchor':'top'})
fig.show() # Sunset / Bluered / Electric
source.02729a84:
#Code by Daniboy370  https://www.kaggle.com/daniboy370/tutorial-web-scraping

import plotly.express as px

thres = 1.3
df_th = df.drop(df[ df['HDI'] > thres ].index)

# color pallete @ https://plotly.com/python/builtin-colorscales/
fig = px.choropleth(df_th, locations='Country or Territory',
                color="HDI", hover_name="Country or Territory",
                    color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Sunset, projection="natural earth")
fig.update_layout(title={'text':'Countries Ranking', 'y':0.95, 'x':0.5, 'xanchor':'center', 'yanchor':'top'})
fig.show() # Sunset / Bluered / Electric

#Code by Marie  https://www.kaggle.com/mariapushkareva/wine-reviews-spacy-bert

data = df['Country or Territory'].replace("Germany").value_counts()
iplot([go.Choropleth(
    locationmode='country names',
    locations=data.index.values,
    text=data.index,
    z=data.values,
    colorscale='portland'
)])
source.50973314:
corr = df.corrwith(df['HDI']).sort_values(ascending = False).to_frame()
corr.columns = ['Correlations']
plt.subplots(figsize = (5,25))
sns.heatmap(corr,annot = True,cmap = 'RdBu',linewidths = 0.4,linecolor = 'black')
plt.title('Rank Correlation w.r.t HDI')

#Code by Marie  https://www.kaggle.com/mariapushkareva/wine-reviews-spacy-bert

print(Fore.BLUE + Style.BRIGHT + 'Number of Countries list in data:', df['Country or Territory'].nunique())
plt.figure(figsize=(14,10))
w = df['Country or Territory'].value_counts().to_frame()[0:20]
#plt.xscale('log')
sns.barplot(x= w['Country or Territory'], y =w.index, data=w, color='crimson', orient='h')
plt.title('Distribution of Countries by Top 20');

source.489fa7ac:
#Code by Marie  https://www.kaggle.com/mariapushkareva/wine-reviews-spacy-bert

from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS, ImageColorGenerator

stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
wordcloud = WordCloud(
    background_color='white',
    stopwords=stopwords,
    colormap='autumn_r',
    max_words=300,
    max_font_size=200, 
    width=1000, height=800,
    random_state=42,
).generate(" ".join(df['Country or Territory'].astype(str)))
print(wordcloud)
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (12,14))
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.title("Country or Territory",fontsize=25)
plt.axis('off')
